source: FDA Orthopedic Device Terminology + ASTM Standards + ISO 21534/5832/5833

titanium_alloy.definition: Titanium alloy containing 6% aluminum and 4% vanadium; most common orthopedic implant material
titanium_alloy.properties: Density 4.43 g/cm³; Ultimate tensile strength ≥860 MPa; Yield strength ≥795 MPa; Elongation ≥10%; Modulus 110 GPa
titanium_alloy.applications: Femoral stems, acetabular shells, spinal rods/screws, trauma plates
titanium_alloy.advantages: Excellent biocompatibility, corrosion resistance, osseointegration with porous coatings
titanium_alloy.disadvantages: Lower wear resistance than CoCr; modulus mismatch with bone (stress shielding)

cobalt_chromium.definition: Cobalt-based alloy with chromium (27-30%) and molybdenum (5-7%); high strength and wear resistance
cobalt_chromium.standard: ASTM F75 (cast), ASTM F1537 (wrought), ASTM F799 (HIPed), ISO 5832-4, 5832-12
cobalt_chromium.properties: Density 8.3-9.2 g/cm³; Ultimate tensile strength 655-1790 MPa (depending on processing); Modulus 210-253 GPa
cobalt_chromium.applications: Femoral heads, femoral knee components, modular neck/heads, bearing surfaces
cobalt_chromium.advantages: Superior wear resistance, high fatigue strength, can be polished to smooth finish (Ra <0.05 μm)
cobalt_chromium.disadvantages: Metal ion release (Co, Cr) in MoM bearings; higher modulus than bone

ultra_high_molecular_weight_polyethylene.definition: Polyethylene with molecular weight 2-6 million g/mol; bearing surface material for articulation
ultra_high_molecular_weight_polyethylene.standard: ASTM F648 (compression molded), ASTM F1046 (ram extruded), ISO 5834-1, 5834-2
ultra_high_molecular_weight_polyethylene.properties: Density 0.93-0.94 g/cm³; Tensile yield strength ≥21 MPa; Elongation at break ≥300%
ultra_high_molecular_weight_polyethylene.types: Conventional UHMWPE, Highly Cross-Linked (HXLPE) via gamma/e-beam irradiation (50-100 kGy), Vitamin E stabilized
ultra_high_molecular_weight_polyethylene.applications: Acetabular liners (hip), tibial inserts (knee), glenoid components (shoulder)
ultra_high_molecular_weight_polyethylene.wear_performance: Conventional: ~0.1-0.2 mm/year linear wear; HXLPE: ~0.02-0.05 mm/year (50-80% reduction)

ceramic.definition: Bioceramics for low-friction, low-wear bearing surfaces in total joint arthroplasty
ceramic.properties: Alumina density 3.98 g/cm³; Grain size <2 μm; Hardness >2000 HV; Modulus 380 GPa
ceramic.applications: Femoral heads (28-40 mm diameter), acetabular liners (ceramic-on-ceramic bearings)
ceramic.advantages: Ultra-low wear (0.001-0.005 mm/year), no metal ions, scratch-resistant
ceramic.disadvantages: Brittle (fracture risk ~0.01-0.05%), sensitive to edge loading, squeaking in CoC bearings (~1-10%)

porous_coating.definition: Surface modification with interconnected pores (50-400 μm) to allow bone infiltration (osseointegration)
porous_coating.standard: ASTM F1854 (testing methods), ASTM F1147 (titanium fiber metal)
porous_coating.types: Sintered beads (CoCr, Ti), plasma spray (Ti, HA), fiber metal (Trabecular Metal, Tritanium)
porous_coating.properties: Pore size 100-400 μm optimal; Porosity 30-60%; Interconnectivity >95%; Shear strength >20 MPa (ASTM F1044)
porous_coating.applications: Acetabular cups, femoral stems (proximal 1/3 or fully coated), tibial baseplates
porous_coating.biological_fixation: Bone ingrowth occurs at 50-200 μm pore size; smaller pores allow ongrowth, larger pores allow through-growth

hydroxyapatite_coating.definition: Calcium phosphate ceramic coating (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2) to enhance osseointegration
hydroxyapatite_coating.standard: ISO 13779-1, ASTM F1609 (thickness/uniformity), ASTM F1044 (bond strength)
hydroxyapatite_coating.properties: Coating thickness 50-200 μm; Crystallinity >62%; Ca/P ratio 1.65-1.76; Tensile bond strength ≥22 MPa
hydroxyapatite_coating.applications: Plasma-sprayed on Ti or CoCr implant surfaces; femoral stems, acetabular cups, dental implants
hydroxyapatite_coating.advantages: Osteoconductive (bone apposition), faster fixation than porous coating alone
hydroxyapatite_coating.disadvantages: Coating delamination risk if improper processing; resorbs over 5-10 years in vivo

osseointegration.definition: Direct structural and functional connection between living bone and implant surface without intervening soft tissue
osseointegration.measurement: Histomorphometry: bone-implant contact (BIC) percentage; Push-out/pull-out testing: interfacial shear strength
osseointegration.success_criteria: BIC ≥40% at 12 weeks (animal studies); Shear strength ≥10 MPa indicates stable fixation
osseointegration.clinical_significance: Cementless fixation requires osseointegration for long-term stability; enhanced by porous coatings and HA
osseointegration.time_course: Initial mechanical interlock (0-6 weeks), bone apposition and ingrowth (6-12 weeks), remodeling (3-6 months)

articulating_surface.definition: Bearing surface finish and geometry affecting wear, friction, and range of motion
articulating_surface.measurement: Surface roughness Ra (arithmetic average); Sphericity/roundness deviation from ideal geometry
articulating_surface.specifications: CoCr femoral head: Ra <0.05 μm, sphericity <5 μm; Polyethylene liner: Ra <3 μm
articulating_surface.test_methods: Profilometry per ISO 4287/4288; CMM (coordinate measuring machine) for geometry
articulating_surface.clinical_significance: Rough surfaces accelerate polyethylene wear; sphericity deviations cause edge loading

wear_characteristics.definition: Volumetric or linear wear measured in joint simulator per ISO 14243 (knee) or ISO 14242 (hip)
wear_characteristics.test_protocol: ISO 14242-1 (hip): 5 million cycles minimum, 1 Hz, Paul load curve, 23° flexion/extension, serum lubricant; ISO 14243-1 (knee): 5 million cycles, displacement control, ISO load curve
wear_characteristics.success_criteria: Hip: <10 mm³/million cycles (HXLPE on CoCr); Knee: <5 mm³/million cycles (HXLPE on CoCr)
wear_characteristics.wear_mechanisms: Adhesive wear (polymer transfer), abrasive wear (third-body particles), fatigue wear (surface/subsurface cracking)
wear_characteristics.clinical_correlation: 1 million cycles ≈ 1 year normal activity; simulator wear predicts osteolysis risk

modularity.definition: Mechanical interlock between implant components (e.g., femoral head-stem, body-neck in modular stems)
modularity.standards: ISO 7206-10 (hip stem taper testing), ASTM F2009 (taper dimensional requirements)
modularity.taper_geometry: 12/14 taper (head-neck): 5° 43' included angle; V40 taper (trunnion): 11° included angle
modularity.failure_modes: Fretting corrosion (mechanically assisted crevice corrosion), dissociation (separation), wear debris
modularity.clinical_significance: Mixed-metal couples (CoCr head on Ti stem) at higher corrosion risk; impaction force affects fixation strength

fatigue_resistance.definition: Ability to withstand cyclic loading without fracture over device lifetime (10 million cycles = ~10 years)
fatigue_resistance.test_standards: ASTM F1717 (spinal constructs), ASTM F1800 (femoral stems), ASTM F1801 (fretting corrosion), ISO 7206-4 (hip stem fatigue)
fatigue_resistance.test_conditions: Simulated worst-case physiologic loading; saline environment (corrosion); 10 million cycles minimum for indefinite life
fatigue_resistance.acceptance_criteria: No fracture at 10 million cycles under specified load; S-N curve with runouts at design load
fatigue_resistance.clinical_significance: Fatigue fracture is catastrophic failure; smaller stems, notches, and corrosion increase risk

range_of_motion.definition: Angular motion before component-component contact (impingement) or dislocation
range_of_motion.test_method: Physical testing or CAD analysis; articulate components to impingement in flexion, extension, adduction, abduction, rotation
range_of_motion.clinical_targets: Hip: ≥120° flexion, ≥30° extension, ≥40° abduction, ≥80° internal rotation (sitting position); Knee: ≥120° flexion
range_of_motion.impingement_consequences: Bearing dislocation (hip), accelerated wear, osteolysis, instability
range_of_motion.design_factors: Head:neck ratio (hip), head size (larger = greater ROM), liner design (elevated rim, neutral/10° anteversion)

cemented_fixation.definition: Polymethyl methacrylate cement provides immediate mechanical interlock between implant and bone
cemented_fixation.cement_standards: ISO 5833 (acrylic bone cement), ASTM F451 (test methods)
cemented_fixation.cement_properties: Compressive strength ≥70 MPa; Bending strength ≥50 MPa; Polymerization temp <90°C; Setting time 5-15 minutes
cemented_fixation.technique_considerations: Cement mantle 2-4 mm thick optimal; pressurization improves penetration; vacuum mixing reduces porosity
cemented_fixation.clinical_use: Preferred for elderly/osteoporotic bone; immediate weight-bearing; long-term aseptic loosening risk

cementless_fixation.definition: Press-fit mechanical stability followed by bone ingrowth/ongrowth into porous coating for long-term fixation
cementless_fixation.design_requirements: Porous coating or HA; interference fit (0.5-2 mm); macro-geometry (fins, splines) for rotational stability
cementless_fixation.initial_stability: Press-fit achieves <40 μm micromotion threshold for bone ingrowth; undersizing reamer by 1-2 mm
cementless_fixation.weight_bearing: Protected weight-bearing (6 weeks) or toe-touch (3 months) until bone ingrowth
cementless_fixation.clinical_use: Younger, active patients; bone stock preservation; revision more difficult (ingrown bone removal)

cup_positioning.definition: Spatial orientation of acetabular component affecting ROM, wear, and dislocation risk
cup_positioning.target_angles: Inclination 40-45° (lateral opening angle); Anteversion 15-25° (anterior opening angle)
cup_positioning.measurement: Intraoperative: mechanical alignment guides; Postoperative: AP pelvis radiograph (inclination), CT (anteversion)
cup_positioning.safe_zone: Lewinnek safe zone (1978): 40° ± 10° inclination, 15° ± 10° anteversion (dislocation rate <4%)
cup_positioning.consequences_of_malposition: Steep inclination (>50°): increased wear, edge loading; High anteversion (>35°): posterior instability

periprosthetic_osteolysis.definition: Inflammatory bone resorption due to wear debris (polyethylene, metal, ceramic particles)
periprosthetic_osteolysis.pathophysiology: Macrophage phagocytosis of particles → cytokine release (TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6) → osteoclast activation → bone resorption
periprosthetic_osteolysis.particle_threshold: Polyethylene: 0.1-1 μm particles most biologically active; Volume >50 mm³/year correlates with osteolysis
periprosthetic_osteolysis.radiographic_criteria: Progressive radiolucency >2 mm in Gruen/DeLee-Charnley zones; endosteal scalloping; cortical thinning
periprosthetic_osteolysis.prevention: HXLPE reduces wear by 50-80%; ceramic bearings eliminate polyethylene; regular radiographic surveillance

aseptic_loosening.definition: Loss of implant-bone fixation without infection; leading cause of revision arthroplasty
aseptic_loosening.mechanisms: Osteolysis-driven (wear debris), inadequate initial fixation (cementless), cement mantle failure (cemented), stress shielding
aseptic_loosening.radiographic_signs: Cemented: cement-bone radiolucency >2 mm, cement fracture; Cementless: progressive subsidence >5 mm, change in alignment >5°
aseptic_loosening.clinical_presentation: Pain (groin pain in hip, knee pain with weight-bearing), reduced function, instability
aseptic_loosening.revision_surgery: Remove loose implant and cement; revise with larger/longer implant or bone graft; outcome worse than primary

adverse_local_tissue_reaction.definition: Soft tissue mass or fluid collection adjacent to implant, associated with metal-on-metal bearings or corrosion
adverse_local_tissue_reaction.etiology: Metal ion hypersensitivity (Type IV delayed hypersensitivity to Cr, Co, Ni); tribocorrosion at modular junctions
adverse_local_tissue_reaction.diagnosis: MRI (MARS protocol for metal artifact reduction); elevated serum Cr/Co (>7 ppb concerning); ultrasound
adverse_local_tissue_reaction.pathology: Aseptic lymphocytic vasculitis-associated lesion (ALVAL); necrosis, macrophage infiltration
adverse_local_tissue_reaction.management: Revision surgery to remove metal bearing and/or corroding junction; ceramic or polyethylene bearing

usage_notes.joint_classifications: Primary = first arthroplasty; Revision = replacement of failed primary; Hemiarthroplasty = replace one side (femoral head only)
usage_notes.bearing_couples: MoP (metal-on-polyethylene) = standard; CoC (ceramic-on-ceramic) = low wear but squeak risk; MoM (metal-on-metal) = largely abandoned due to ALTR
usage_notes.cement_antibiotics: Gentamicin or tobramycin added to cement (1-2 g per 40 g cement) for infection prophylaxis
usage_notes.size_specifications: Femoral head diameter: 22-44 mm (larger = greater ROM, higher volumetric wear); Stem offset: standard, high, extra-high (restore leg length/offset)
